In a large mixing bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, salt, and sugar.
In a jug measure the milk.
Separate the eggs.
Place the eggs in the bowl of a stand mixer.
Add the yolk and vanilla essence to the milk.
Whisk together.
Pour in flour mixture.
Stir very gently until about combined.
Melt butter.
Stir butter.
Continue to mix very gently until combined.
Beat in egg whites until stiff.
Preheat waffle iron.
Slowly fold in egg whites into the batter.
Scoop the batter in batches onto waffle irons.
Cook the batter according to its directions.
Remove, immediately.
Serve with maple syrup and fruit.

In a large bowl beat sugar and vegetable oil to blend, using an electric mixer.
Lightly oil 2 9x6 loaf pans.
Add the eggs one at a time, then add the vanilla, mix after each addition.
Add bananas to combine.
Stir to combine.
In another large bowl, whisk together the fluid, cinnamon, baking soda, baking powder and salt.
Stir the flour mixture into the banana mixture 2 or 3 times until just combined.
Spoon evenly into loaf pans and fill them with batter about 3-4 ways to the top of each pan.
Fold in blueberries.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees F.
Preheat oven.
Insert toothpick in middle of loaf.
Bake in the oven for 60-70 minutes or until the toothpick comes out clean.
The loaf pan on a wire shelf, cooled for 10 minutes.
Remove pan from pan.
Place the Pan on a shelf.
Cool completely.

Preheat oil, you and the loaf pan.
In a large mixing bowl, add the flour, oats, salt, cinnamon, pumpkin pie spice, and baking powder.
Stir to combine.
In another mixing bowl, beat eggs with an electric hand mixer.
In another mixing bowl, then add sugar.
Beat until well combined.
Add the oil, yogurt, pumpkin, and vanilla.
Beat the oil, yogurt, pumpkin, and vanilla well to mix.
Fake the mini chips into the batter.
Pour into loaf pan.
Insert toothpick in the middle.
Bake for 1 hour or until toothpick comes out clean.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees, scoop out loaf pan.

Pull the leaves off the cauliflower.
Cut the core out in kind of cone shape.
Break the wow or cut the wow regularly in about 1.5 inches.
Put the wow into the steamer insert.
Bring about 1 tbsp water to a boil in a steam pot, cover.
About 1 tbsp water add to about 1 inch of water inserted, cover.
About 1 tbsp water add to about 1 inch of water inserted cover and cook about 1 tbsp water for about 20 minutes (you may poke a paring knife through the stem or you may still feel a little texture in about 1 inch of water inserted ).
Dump about half of the cauliflower into the food processor.
Pour in to about half the cauliflower the nut milk, puree about half the cauliflower until smooth.
Now dump the rest of the cauliflower on top.
The rest of the cauliflower now puree the cauliflower again.
You need to stop, scrape and stir the puree a few times.
Add to the puree the butter, salt, pepper and garlic until smooth.
Smoothly mix about half the cauliflower.
Taste the cauliflower pure to season.
If you do n’t eat immediately, you can reheat the dear purée on the same pan over low heat.
Serve the purée hot.

Preheat oven to 350°.
In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, baking soda, baking powder and salt.
Using a stand mixer with the paddle attachment, beat the butter, cream cheese, light brown sugar, granulated sugar and vanilla extract until the mixture becomes light and fluffy.
Add eggs one at a time, making sure they are fully incorporated, scraping down the sides as needed.
Add the dry mixture a third at a time until mixed.
Stir in the chocolate chips.
Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
Using a cookie scoop, place 1-2 tablespoon mounds onto the parchment paper about 2 inches apart.
Bake the cookies for 12-14 minutes or until golden brown.
Remove from oven and let cool for 5 minutes before transferring to a cooling rack.
For best results, place dough in refrigerator overnight or for at least 30 minutes before baking.

Combine yeast, water, salt, oil, and 2 cups flour in the bowl of a stand mixer.
Using the dough hook, mix on speed 2 for about 1 minute.
Clings.
Add remaining flour, 1/2 cup at a time, until the dough to the the sides of the bowl.
Clings hook and hook.
Continue kneading for an additional two minutes.
Place dough in a greased bowl (I often use the stand mixer bowl,).
Which I remove the dough from, grease.
And then return the dough to.
Turn to grease the top.
Cover with a towel or plastic wrap.
This recipe can be divided into 4 pieces to make smaller, thin crust pizzas, or can be divided in half to make 2 larger, medium-thick crust pizzas.
And place in a warm place.
To rise for an hour.
Make pizza according to your favorite directions.

Preheat oil and loaf pan.
Add flour, oat, salt, cinnamon, pumpkin pie spice, baking powder, and flour, oats to large mixing bowl.
Stir it to combine.
In another mixing bowl, beat eggs with an electric hand mixer.
In another mixing bowl, then add sugar to eggs.
Beat eggs until well combined.
Add oils, yogurt, pumpkin and vanilla to eggs.
To eggs beat eggs to mix well.
Fake mini chips into batter.
Pour eggs into loaf pan.
Insert toothpick in middle.
Bake eggs 1 hour or until toothpick comes out clean.
Preheat oven to 350 degrees, and grease loaf pan.

Add the flour mixture and mix on low speed just until blended .
Transfer the dough onto a piece of plastic wrap and wrap tightly .
In a medium bowl , whisk together both flours , the baking soda and salt . 
When ready to bake the cookies , preheat the oven to 350 degrees F. 
Refrigerate for at least 2 hours , or up to 5 days .
Bake for another 6 to 8 minutes , or until the cookies are dark golden brown .
Line two baking sheets with parchment paper or a silicone baking mat .
Store in an airtight container for up to 5 days .
Bake the cookies for 10 minutes and then rotate the baking sheet .
Let cool for a minute on the baking sheets , then transfer to a cooling rack .
Transfer to the baking sheet.
On a lightly floured surface , roll out the dough and cut into 3-inch squares .
Let cool completely ( they will crisp up as they cool ) .
In a large bowl , combine the butter , brown sugar and honey .

Using the paddle attachment, beat the butter, cream cheese, light brown sugar, granulated sugar and vanilla extract until the mixture becomes light and fluffy.
In a medium bowl, whisk together flour, baking soda, baking powder, and salt.
Add eggs, one at a time, and make sure they are fully incorporated.
One at the time, add dry mixture until mixed.
Make sure the eggs are fully incorporated and scrape down the sides as necessary.
Stir in the chocolate chips.
Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
Using a cookie scoop, place a tablespoon-2 mounds about 2 inches apart on the parchment paper.

Bake the cookies for 12-14 minutes or until brown.
Remove from oven.
Let cool for 5 minutes.
Transfer to cooling rack.
Transfer dough.
Place dough in refrigerator for overnight or at least 30 minutes for the best result.

Pull the leaves off the cauliflower and cut out the core in a kind of cone-shaped section.
Break or cut the florets into small, regular pieces (about 1 1/2 inch) and put them in the steamer insert.
Bring about 1 inch of water to a boil in the steamer pot, add the insert, cover, and cook for about 20 minutes, or until you can poke a paring knife into the stems and you can feel that there 's still a little texture there.
Dump about half of the cauliflower into a food processor.
Pour in the nut milk and purée until smooth.
Now dump the rest of the cauliflower on top and purée again.
You 'll need to stop and scrape and stir the purée a few times.
Once smooth, add in the butter, salt, pepper and garlic and mix.
Taste for seasoning and serve hot.
(You can reheat over low heat in the same pan if you 're not eating immediately.).

Using a paddle attachment, beat butter, cream cheese, light brown sugar, granulated sugar, and vanilla extract until mixture becomes light and fluffy.
